name: Family Preservation Services (FPS)
summary: An intensive, short-term, in-home therapeutic intervention designed to stabilize families in crisis, prevent unnecessary out-of-home placements of children, and strengthen family functioning.
description: Family Preservation Services (FPS) are structured, evidence-based interventions that provide intensive, home-based support to families experiencing crises that put children at risk of removal. These services focus on keeping families together whenever safely possible by addressing immediate crises, improving parenting skills, enhancing family relationships, and connecting families with community resources. FPS practitioners typically offer 24/7 availability, flexible scheduling, and hands-on guidance tailored to each family’s needs.

metadata.session_duration: 1–2 hours (variable, often multiple sessions per week)

primary_indications: Families at risk of child removal
contraindications: Severe safety risks to children that require immediate removal
Parents with untreated severe psychiatric conditions or active substance abuse without stabilization
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe, home-based, and supportive. Risks may include inadequate safety planning if families are highly unstable.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate—supported by government reports and child welfare evaluations, but outcomes vary by model and fidelity.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Studies show FPS can reduce foster care placements, improve family functioning, and lower long-term child welfare involvement when delivered with high fidelity.

sections.text: FPS works by providing intensive, in-home support to families at risk of breakdown. Therapists model effective parenting strategies, teach conflict resolution, help families build safety plans, and link them to community resources. The immediate crisis is stabilized while long-term skills are strengthened to reduce the likelihood of child removal.

sections.preparation: Referral from child welfare agencies, courts, or schools. Families are assessed for safety and readiness.
procedure: Therapists provide multiple weekly home visits.
Parents receive coaching, skill-building, and emotional support.
Families are connected to housing, employment, and health resources.
sections.frequency: Several times per week during the crisis phase.
sections.duration: Typically 4–12 weeks of intensive intervention, followed by ongoing monitoring or step-down services.

sections.pre_session: Therapist checks in with family on immediate needs and safety concerns.
sections.treatment_phase: Interactive skill-building, conflict resolution, and crisis planning.
sections.post_session: Review progress, assign home practice, ensure safety until next visit.

uncommon: Relapse into unsafe family patterns after treatment
rare: Placement disruption if risks cannot be reduced

absolute: Active danger to children requiring immediate removal

ideal_candidates: Families with children at risk of placement
Parents open to intensive in-home support
Families facing temporary crises (financial, relational, behavioral)

practitioner: Social workers trained in FPS models
facility: In-home service delivery with agency support

studies: Fraser MW, Pecora PJ, Haapala DA. (1991). Families in Crisis: The Impact of Intensive Family Preservation Services.
National Family Preservation Network (NFPN) evaluations of FPS programs.
sections.limitations: Effectiveness depends on implementation fidelity and available community resources.

sections.typical_session_cost: Varies—often funded by child welfare agencies
sections.total_treatment_cost: Lower than foster care placement costs
sections.cost_effectiveness: High when preventing costly out-of-home placements.

sections.culturally-diverse-families: Adaptations often made for cultural sensitivity.

items: FPS originated in the U.S. as a child welfare reform strategy.
Different states and agencies use varying models (e.g., Homebuilders).
Program intensity and duration vary by jurisdiction.
